{"success":true,"issue":{"number":217,"title":"Proof toggle: Lean code jumping/flickering during animation","state":"OPEN","labels":["ai-authored","origin:agent","bug:visual","bug:regression","area:sbs:chapter","impact:visual"],"url":"https://github.com/e-vergo/SLS-Strange-Loop-Station/issues/217","body":"## Problem

When clicking proof toggle on any page, the Lean code jumps around its box during the animation. It always ends up in the correct final state, but the transition is visually jarring.

**Behavior:**
- Happens 100% of the time on all proof toggles, all pages
- All Lean code (signature and proof body) jumps vertically during animation
- LaTeX proof toggle on the same page works smoothly without jumping

## Root Cause Investigation

The problematic callback was added in commit `2063d35` (fix for issue #175 "one-line gap"):
```javascript
sbsContainer.find('.lean-proof-body').slideDown(300, function() {
    $(this).css('display', 'inline');
});
```

The working version before that commit used `slideUp()`/`slideDown()` without callbacks.

## Attempted Fixes

1. **CSS transitions with max-height**: Added transition styles, but caused horizontal layout issues during animation (proof body appeared to the right instead of below)
2. **Restored pre-regression code**: Removed the callback and used simple `slideUp()`/`slideDown()`, but flickering persists

## Related Issue: Styling Unification

Paper pages should use the same [show]/[hide] text proof toggle styling as blueprint pages, not the modern button style. Added `.ar5iv-paper` overrides to `paper.css` but modern styling still appears.

## Files Involved

- `toolchain/dress-blueprint-action/assets/plastex.js` (lines 69-85)
- `toolchain/dress-blueprint-action/assets/common.css` (lines 432-436)
- `toolchain/dress-blueprint-action/assets/blueprint.css` (lines 1350-1406)
- `toolchain/dress-blueprint-action/assets/paper.css` (end of file)
- `toolchain/Dress/Dress/Render/SideBySide.lean` (HTML structure)

## Expected Behavior

Lean proof body should animate smoothly like the LaTeX proof content - no jumping, no flickering, just a clean slide animation.

---
**Agent Context (auto-populated)**
- Global State: {"skill": "task", "substate": "alignment"}
- Current Epoch Entries: 8
- Last Epoch: 1770256793

🤖 Logged autonomously via sbs_issue_log","created_at":"2026-02-05T02:29:01Z"},"error":null}

{"success":true,"issue":{"number":175,"title":"One-line gap between Lean proof declaration and proof body on toggle","state":"CLOSED","labels":["ai-authored","origin:agent","bug:visual","area:sbs:theme","impact:visual"],"url":"https://github.com/e-vergo/SLS-Strange-Loop-Station/issues/175","body":"## Description

When expanding a proof via the fold/unfold toggle, there is a visible blank line gap between the Lean signature (declaration) and the proof body in the right-side code column.

## Root Cause

Two factors combine:

1. jQuery's `slideDown()` (in `plastex.js:95` and `verso-code.js:204`) sets `display: block` on `<code class="lean-proof-body">`. The `<code>` element is normally inline.

2. The proof body HTML content starts with `\n  ` (newline + indentation). Inside a `<pre>` with `white-space: pre`, `display: block` forces a line break, plus the content `\n` adds another — producing a visible blank line gap.

## Affected Files

- `toolchain/dress-blueprint-action/assets/plastex.js:91-95` (slideUp/slideDown)
- `toolchain/dress-blueprint-action/assets/verso-code.js:203-205` (slideDown)
- `toolchain/Dress/Dress/Render/SideBySide.lean:142` (HTML generation)

## Fix Options

1. Strip leading `\n` from proof body content during HTML generation in `SideBySide.lean`
2. Use `display: inline` instead of `display: block` for the toggle (CSS override for slideDown behavior)
3. Both

## Testing Gap

No browser-driven test validates whitespace between signature and proof body elements. A `/qa` test checking for unexpected blank lines in expanded proofs would catch this.

1→Hey everyone,
     2→
     3→I'm proud to present something I have been working on recently: I ported LeanBlueprint over from python and built a pure lean deployment pipeline around it. This takes the first steps towards some of the Lean FRO goals mentioned in Leo's talk at Lean Together 2026. Among other things, this includes:
     4→* A Verso driven blueprint with many of the features one would expect
     5→* A first pass at ‘One click websites’
     6→* Integrated paper generation, duplicating the workflow of the blueprint
     7→* A platform for running and displaying kernel/soundness checks on a repo
     8→
     9→Example repos:
    10→
    11→[Minimal test repo showing all features](https://e-vergo.github.io/SBS-Test/index.html)
    12→[Complete project with will blueprint/paper generation and integration](https://e-vergo.github.io/General_Crystallographic_Restriction/index.html)
    13→[Full scale existing project, no paper](https://e-vergo.github.io/PrimeNumberTheoremAnd/index.html) (PNT)
    14→
    15→This was a massive effort with some fun technical details, but these are the big things:
    16→* This forks [LeanArchitect](https://github.com/e-vergo/LeanArchitect) and turns it into a general purpose tagging system 
    17→* [Dress](https://github.com/e-vergo/Dress) uses LeanArchitect as the hook for extraction and ‘dresses’ the lean by generating all of the relevant reusable assets during the build/elab process (verso info, tex files, etc.). 
    18→* [Runway](https://github.com/e-vergo/Runway) (think fashion show) is the LeanBlueprint port. It builds the side-by-side blueprint, dependency graph, and paper (html and pdf) and wraps it in a webpage
    19→* CI is controlled via [dress-blueprint-action](https://github.com/e-vergo/dress-blueprint-action) for easy integration and use in the [lean project repo template](https://github.com/leanprover-community/LeanProject)
    20→* It is entirely vibe coded and not ready for prime time, but it could be with some work.
    21→
    22→Assuming success with a lot of things, not much would change in terms of how one interfaces with a lean project using the LeanArchitect system. All you would have to do is tag a few additional things in the blueprint attribute to support the messaging/notification features, most of which are represented on the dashboard. These tags are fairly ad-hoc and can be updated easily, including adding new ones. Happy to answer any questions you guys have.
    23→
    24→Best,
    25→
    26→Eric
    27→
    28→[Screenshot 2026-01-29 at 5.28.15 PM.png](/user_uploads/3121/fGuYIWK51neWllVn1nFzEeZN/Screenshot-2026-01-29-at-5.28.15PM.png)
    29→
    30→[Screenshot 2026-01-29 at 5.12.19 PM.png](/user_uploads/3121/d9NoxAT-iYlCA6-ujq9if0Vd/Screenshot-2026-01-29-at-5.12.19PM.png)
    31→
    32→[Screenshot 2026-01-29 at 5.11.49 PM.png](/user_uploads/3121/9ld7IAvb1KeIbbResIQ5SdG7/Screenshot-2026-01-29-at-5.11.49PM.png)

tool_calls.input_summary: {"file_path": "/Users/eric/GitHub/Side-By-Side-Blueprint/post_draft.txt", "content": "Hey everyone,\n\nI'm proud to present something I've been working on: **Side-by-Side Blueprint** \u2014 a pure Lea...

input_full.content:
Hey everyone,

I'm proud to present something I've been working on: **Side-by-Side Blueprint** — a pure Lean port of LeanBlueprint with an integrated deployment pipeline. No Python, no external dependencies, just Lake and Lean.

This takes first steps toward some of the Lean FRO goals Leo mentioned at Lean Together 2026. The highlights:

**User-Facing Features:**
- **Side-by-side proof display** — LaTeX theorem statements paired with Lean code, toggleable proof bodies
- **Project dashboard** — Key theorems, blocked items, messages, and technical debt at a glance
- **Interactive dependency graph** — Status-colored nodes, click-through to theorems, cycle detection
- **Integrated paper generation** — Same pipeline produces blueprint, HTML paper, and PDF
- **6-tier status tracking** — From "not ready" through "mathlib-ready", auto-detected from your code
- **One-click websites** — CI action generates and deploys everything

**Example repos:**
- [Minimal test repo](https://e-vergo.github.io/SBS-Test/index.html) — Shows all features
- [GCR](https://e-vergo.github.io/General_Crystallographic_Restriction/index.html) — Complete project with blueprint + paper
- [PNT](https://e-vergo.github.io/PrimeNumberTheoremAnd/index.html) — Full-scale existing project

**Why not just use LeanBlueprint?**
- **Pure Lean** — No Python install, no version mismatches, simpler CI
- **Integrated pipeline** — Blueprint, paper, and PDF from the same build
- **Richer metadata** — Dashboard messaging, debt tracking, status progression

**Technical stack** (for the curious):
- [LeanArchitect](https://github.com/e-vergo/LeanArchitect) — General-purpose tagging system (`@[blueprint]` attribute)
- [Dress](https://github.com/e-vergo/Dress) — Extracts and "dresses" Lean with reusable assets during elaboration
- [Runway](https://github.com/e-vergo/Runway) — The LeanBlueprint port; builds blueprint, dependency graph, paper
- [dress-blueprint-action](https://github.com/e-vergo/dress-blueprint-action) — CI action for easy integration

**Caveats:** It's entirely vibe coded and not ready for prime time, but it could be with some work. Looking for feedback on what features matter most and what rough edges need smoothing first.

Happy to answer questions!

Best,
Eric

*Screenshots below: Dashboard view, dependency graph, side-by-side proof display*

[Screenshot 2026-01-29 at 5.28.15 PM.png](/user_uploads/3121/fGuYIWK51neWllVn1nFzEeZN/Screenshot-2026-01-29-at-5.28.15PM.png)

[Screenshot 2026-01-29 at 5.12.19 PM.png](/user_uploads/3121/d9NoxAT-iYlCA6-ujq9if0Vd/Screenshot-2026-01-29-at-5.12.19PM.png)

[Screenshot 2026-01-29 at 5.11.49 PM.png](/user_uploads/3121/9ld7IAvb1KeIbbResIQ5SdG7/Screenshot-2026-01-29-at-5.11.49PM.png)

- The LaTeX side shows the proof content
- The Lean side shows the proof body (the `-- Even though we have a proof...` comments and `trivial`)

Looking at the Lean code column:
```lean
theorem foundation : True := by
-- Even though we have a proof, the manual notReady flag takes precedence
-- This tests that manual status flags override auto-detection
trivial -- simple proof for testing purposes
```

The animation already happened so I can't see the flickering in a static screenshot. But I notice that the Lean proof body is displayed directly below the signature, which looks correct.

However, I can't see if there's flickering or jumping without actually watching the animation. The user says flickering persists.

Let me think about what might be causing the flickering. The issue describes:
- The Lean code jumps around during animation
- It ends up in the correct final state

Let me look at what happens when jQuery slideDown runs on an inline element inside a pre:

1. CSS: `.lean-proof-body { display: none; }`
2. User clicks toggle
3. jQuery slideDown:
   - Sets display: block (to calculate height)
   - Animates height from 0 to full height
   - During animation, element is display: block
4. Animation completes, element stays display: block

The problem is step 3 - when the `<code>` becomes `display: block`, it shifts from being inline with the signature to being on a new line. And since the proof body content starts with `\n`, you get an extra line.

Wait, let me look at the current HTML structure more carefully. In the screenshot, the Lean code looks like:
```
theorem foundation : True := by
-- Even though we have a proof...
```

So the signature (`theorem foundation : True := by`) is on line 1, and the proof body (`-- Even though...`, `trivial`) starts on line 2. 

This is the core issue. When the `<code class="lean-proof-body">` transitions from `display: none` to `display: block` during the slideDown animation, it forces a line break that wasn't there before, causing the visible text to shift and jump around. I need to examine the actual HTML structure to understand how the signature and body are nested.

The user opened the blueprint.css file, which is relevant to our task. Let me continue analyzing.

Looking at the HTML output, I notice:

1. The `.lean-proof-body` currently has `style="display: inline;"` - this shows that something set it to inline after the slideDown finished. But wait, the current code doesn't have the callback to set display:inline...

Actually wait - looking at the code again, the current plastex.js just uses `slideDown()` without a callback. But the element shows `display: inline`. Let me check if jQuery preserved the inline style or if there's some other CSS at play.

Actually, I bet what's happening is:
1. Initially: `display: none` (from CSS)
2. slideDown runs: temporarily sets `display: block` during animation
3. slideDown completes: leaves element with `display: block`

But the HTML shows `display: inline`... Let me check if there's something else going on. Maybe there was a previous click that set it to inline via some other mechanism?

Actually, looking more carefully at the HTML:
```html
<code class="hl lean lean-proof-body" style="display: inline;">
```

There's an inline style `display: inline`. This suggests either:
1. The callback code is still active somewhere (but I read the file and it wasn't there)
2. Some other code is setting this
3. The build hasn't picked up the latest changes

Let me look at what the current state of the code is in the deployed version. Actually, let me check if the asset files are from the submodule or copied elsewhere.

Actually wait - the build process copies assets from dress-blueprint-action. Let me check if the deployed version matches the source.

No output means the files are identical. So the deployed version matches the source. But then why is `display: inline` being set?

Let me look at the verso-code.js file which was mentioned in issue #175. It might have similar toggle logic.

Found it! The culprit is in `verso-code.js` lines 203-206:```javascript
$(leanProofBody).slideDown(300, function() {
    $(this).css('display', 'inline');});
```

So BOTH files handle the proof toggle:1. **plastex.js** (lines 78-82): Uses simple `slideUp()`/`slideDown()` WITHOUT callback2. **verso-code.js** (lines 203-206): Uses `slideDown()` WITH callback to set `display: inline`

The issue is that BOTH are running when you click the proof heading:1. plastex.js runs first (handles the click directly)2. verso-code.js runs 50ms later (via setTimeout) and runs its own slideDown with the callback

This creates a double-animation and the callback in verso-code.js is setting `display: inline` at the end.

The solution is to consolidate the logic into one place and remove the callback. We need to:
1. Remove the callback from verso-code.js OR
2. Remove the duplicate handler from verso-code.js entirely (since plastex.js handles it)

Actually, looking at the comment on line 186-187:> Sync Lean proof body visibility with LaTeX proof toggle using jQuery animations> Note: plastex.js now uses .expanded class on proof_wrapper instead of text changes

This suggests verso-code.js was added as a "sync" mechanism, but if plastex.js already handles the Lean proof body toggle, we don't need verso-code.js to do it again.Let me confirm the user's concern - they said the issue started after #175 was fixed. Looking at commit 2063d35 (the #175 fix), it modified BOTH plastex.js and verso-code.js:> 2 files changed, 6 insertions(+), 2 deletions(-)

So the callback was added to BOTH files. When we reverted plastex.js, we didn't revert verso-code.js! That's why flickering persists.


The git history for verso-code.js should show when this sync mechanism was introduced and whether it was part of the same #175 fix.
No output - let me check from the correct directory.

Confirmed. The last change to verso-code.js was in commit 2063d35 (the #175 fix). All the subsequent changes were to plastex.js only. So verso-code.js still has the callback.The fix is simple: remove the callback from verso-code.js, making it use simple `slideDown()` like plastex.js now does.

Actually wait - there's ANOTHER issue here. Both plastex.js AND verso-code.js are trying to toggle the same element. This creates:1. First animation from plastex.js (simple slideDown)2. Second animation 50ms later from verso-code.js (slideDown with callback)

This double-animation is likely causing issues. The fix should be to either:1. Remove the verso-code.js handler entirely (let plastex.js handle everything)2. Remove the plastex.js handler and let verso-code.js handle it3. Keep both but remove the callback from verso-code.jsOption 1 is cleanest if plastex.js already handles everything. Let me check what verso-code.js was originally supposed to do - the comment says "Sync Lean proof body visibility with LaTeX proof toggle". This suggests it was added to sync the Lean column with the LaTeX proof toggle, but plastex.js already does this (lines 77-82).

Looking at the code flow:1. User clicks `.proof_heading`
2. plastex.js handler fires immediately:   - Toggles `.expanded` class   - Calls `slideUp()` or `slideDown()` on `.lean-proof-body`3. verso-code.js handler fires 50ms later:
   - Checks if `.expanded` class is present   - Calls `slideDown(300, callback)` or `slideUp(300)` on same element

So the Lean proof body is being animated TWICE:1. First by plastex.js (instantly)
2. Then by verso-code.js (50ms later, with callback)


The flickering stems from this overlapping animation sequence. Removing the verso-code.js handler entirely would be the cleanest solution since plastex.js already manages the Lean proof body visibility.
